title: A history of rangeland events in the Cienega Watershed

events.title: Cretaceous events   145 to 66 million years ago
events.description: Cretaceous experienced warm climate, high sea levels, inland seas, mass extinction

events.title: PaleoIndian Period in Watershed
events.description: Humans hunting big game (megafauna, mammoth, bison, antelope) smaller animals and gathering plants

events.title: End of Ice Age Ecological Transition
events.description: Temperatures cooler than now, less arid; grassland with marshes

events.title: PaleoIndian Period human settlement continues
events.description: Humans hunting large animals and game

events.title: Archaic settlements and activities
events.description: Patterns of hunting and intensive plant collecting with seasonal mobile camps

events.title: Climatic transition period
events.description: Warmer and drier than now, channel-cutting with erosion peirods

events.title: Temperatures drop, erosional events
events.description: incisions and filling events on Cienega Creek, buried archaeological sites

events.title: Archaic Farmers: Early Farming along Cienega Creek
events.description: Fields, pithouses, small hamlets, villages along Cienega Creek, less mobile; farming on floodpains resulted in deep buried agricultural sites

events.title: Moisture and Temperatures similar to today
events.description: Agriculture possible through irrigation, flooding

events.title: Widespread farming communities and settled  village lifestyle
events.description: Large pithouses, courtyards, ceramics, settled life; larger villages, some ballcourts

events.title: Climate drying, Hohokam strategies
events.description: Some large Hohokam site, public structures; ag aided with check dams terraces; long-occupied sites at I/10 and Cienega Creek; plus smaller ag sites

events.title: Proto-historic Apache and Sobiapuri Native Americans living in the watershed
events.description: Sobiapuri communities found at multiple locations including Colossal Cave

events.title: Spanich Contact with Apache or other native groups
events.description: Apache and Sobiapuri living in area where Coronado crossed

events.title: Hohokam and protohistoric use Cienega Creek and Colossal Cave area
events.description: Colossal Cave used as a shrine by Native Americans
events.source: #The Timeline: The intertwined histories of Colossal Cve and La Posta Quemada Ranch, MK Maierhauser, E. Lendell Cockrum 2000

events.title: Dryland farming possible along floodplains, washes and with irrigtion
events.description: Proto-historic, post-Hohokam groups living in smaller communities with diverse economics

events.title: Spansh presence initiated in Native American areas
events.description: Livestock introduced by Fr. Kino

events.title: Temperatures and moisture vary as in today's watershed climate
Jesuit Father Eusebio Francisco Kino expores S. AZ Pimera Alta
Sobaipuri probably moved west to avoid Apache expansion
events.description: Some groups may have dispersed east as well

events.title: Euroamerican settlement spread during the Spanish Colonial period; Tucson presidio
events.description: Spread of livestock and new plants during Spanish Colonial period

events.title: US General Land Office established 1812
events.description: To acquire federal lands; later administered Homestead Act

events.title: Mexican Independence
events.description: 1821 Mexico wins independence from Spain

events.title: San Ignacio del Babocamari land grant: $390 for 7,120,000 acres
events.description: See Collins 2008 for details
events.source: #Collins Glendon E., 2008, A History of the Lands in the National Audubon Society's Research Ranch near Elgin, in Santa Cruz County, Arizona (http://researchranch.audubon.org

events.title: Cattle became dominant regional ecological force, an exotic influence on native ecosystems
events.description: beginning in 1800s and continuing into today
events.source: #Bock, Carl E. & Jane H. Bock. 2000.  View from Bald Hill. University of California Press

events.title: 1846-1848 US war with Mexico ending in the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo (1848)
1848 Arizona lands added to the United States
1848 Emory boundary survey includes Sonoita Plains
events.description: Emory boundary survey reports on wildlife etcs in region.  Crew gets lost in Sonoita Plains, confused by 3 rivers. Reports  marshes, bogs

events.title: 1849 Department of the Interior established
events.description: General Land Office transferred to DOI

events.title: 1849 Anglo infux into area and the west
events.description: California gold mines spurred large movements into West

events.title: 1853 Gadsen Purchase completed bringing watershed into US
events.description: Geography dictates history and politics: Gadsden Purchase provided the US with enough SK Iland topography to run a railroad between mountains

events.title: 1854 Earliest American settlements in the Gadsen Purchase area were in the Sonoita Valley
events.source: #Wagoner, J. J. (1952). History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin 23(2):1-131.

events.title: 1856, February—the US flag was raised over Tucson
events.source: #Wagoner, J. J. (1952). History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin 23(2):1-131.

events.title: 1857-early 1880s  Various stage lines operate across AZ from San Diego, CA to San Antonio, TX
events.description: Civil War provided a 4-year interruption of the stage lines

events.title: 1861 Confederate Territory; civil war begins in April
events.description: Flags change in Tucson

events.title: 1862 Homestead Act passed; General Land Office was  in Florence
events.description: Opened up lands in the watershed for homesteading; 160 acres after reside/cultivate for 5 years

events.title: 1863 A Lincoln creates Arizona Terirtory
events.description: Fro western half of New Mexico Terriory

events.title: 1872 General Mining Law identifies mineral lands subject to exploration, occupation & purchase under stipulated conditions
events.description: Patented provision gave lands into private ownership; Rosemont pit

events.title: Earthquake damages watershed structures
events.description: Earthquake & aftershocks felt from Phoenix to Puerto Vallarta, Mexico and from Yuma to Santa Fe, NM; May & Nov

events.title: Multiple floods, also forced railroad out of flood plain
events.description: Drought and flood cyle 1890s, severe overgrazing, arroyo formation triggered

events.title: mid-1870s Southern Pacific Line operates a stagecoach stop at what is today part of LaPosta Quemada Ranch.
events.description: According to Edward Vail, by 1875 a burned stage station existed, hence Posta Quemada -Burnt Station
events.source: #The Timeline: The intertwined histories of Colossal Cve and La Posta Quemada Ranch, MK Maierhauser, E. Lendell Cockrum 2000

events.title: Beavers gone from Cienega Creek
events.description: Beavers lost from Gila River System including Cienega Creek

events.title: 1878 Solomon Lick builds the Mtn Springs Hotel and Stage Station
events.description: About a mile west of the burnt station  La Posta Quemada Ranch's Mtn Springs Grove located at that spot today.
events.source: #The Timeline: The intertwined histories of Colossal Cve and La Posta Quemada Ranch, MK Maierhauser, E. Lendell Cockrum 2000

events.title: 1878 National Mail and Transportation Company takes over from the Southern Pacific Mail Line
1879 Colossal Cave discovered by  Solomon Lick
events.description: Searching for stray cows, discoves an entrance to 'either a very extensive old mine, or a wonderful cave'; explores today's Colossal Cave
events.tags: Colossal Cave Mountain Park, Land Forms (Caves)

events.title: December 15, 1880 the Southern Pacific Railroad is connected with the Santa Fe Railroad at Deming, NM. Train eliminates most stage lines including Nat Mail & T Co., ; no need for Mtn Springs as a stage station.
events.description: By April 1880, Southern Pacific Railroad tracks made it to Punta de Agua where the Pantano Wash and Cienega Creek meet along the old wagon rd.  Railroad is constructed as a levee in the broad floodplain of Cienega. Vail's Siding wa build on the last stretch of that land before the railraod traks entered Cienega Creek.
events.source: #The Timeline: The intertwined histories of Colossal Cve and La Posta Quemada Ranch, MK Maierhauser, E. Lendell Cockrum 2000

events.title: Severe drought for 2 years
events.description: Up to 75% of cattle died after nearly all forage had beed decimated;   ecosystem had not co-evolved with this type of grazing intensity
events.source: #Bock, Carl E. & Jane H. Bock. 2000.  View from Bald Hill. University of California Press

events.title: Total Wreck Mine on Empire Ranch
1884 Great Train Robbery that never was gives rise to Bandit Legend
events.source: #The Timeline: The intertwined histories of Colossal Cve and La Posta Quemada Ranch, MK Maierhauser, E. Lendell Cockrum 2000

events.title: 1887 May 3, first of 4 earthquakes or aftershocks; one estimated 7.2 causes banks of San Pedro R to become 15-20 ft deep; later shock Nov 11, cracks wooden depot bldgs in Pantano.
events.description: Tombstone reports significant aftershock on May 30; Breaks up playas, forms Mustang Mts skyline used in Red River film; aftershocks felt from Phoenix to Puerto Vallarta, Mexico and from Yuma to Santa Fe
events.source: #The Timeline: The intertwined histories of Colossal Cve and La Posta Quemada Ranch, MK Maierhauser, E. Lendell Cockrum 2000

events.title: 1887-1889 – many floods and had to move railroad out of flood plain
events.description: 1888 1000 Chinese workman brought in to lay new tracks

events.title: 1887 Train robberies.  Result in posse discovering 2 more caves
events.description: Colossal Cave Mountain Park

events.title: 1887 Forest Management 'Organic' Act, transfers fire/forestry to General Land Office
International Boundary Water Commission formed
Early 1890s exploration into 'Mtn Springs Cave' resulted in number of images
events.description: Ranch now oeprated by William Shaw (thru 1918) (Colossal Cave Mtn. Park)

events.title: Greaterville gold deposits 'worked-out' with traditional panning techniques.
events.description: Ky Camp   early 1890s

events.title: 1891, 1892 Severe drought. Up to 75% of cattle died after nearly all forage had beed decimated.
events.description: LL:RR:  ecosystem had not co-evolved with this type of grazing intensity
events.source: #Bock, Carl E. & Jane H. Bock. 2000.  View from Bald Hill. University of California Press

events.title: Drought and flood cyle 1890s, severe overgrazing, arroyo formation triggered
events.description: Rangeland ecology fragile in arid landscapes (see Bahr 1991)

events.title: 1898 Spanish American War
James Steson acquires Kentucky Camp mining claims, water rights
events.description: acquires mining claims, water rights and reservoirs for a large scale hydraulic gold mining operation. George McAneny and James Stetson form the Santa Rita Water and Mining Company on October 3rd.

events.title: The first federal land survey in the Research Ranch area was done in June 1902, to establish boundaries of San Ignacio del Babacomari Grant.
events.description: Research Ranch.  See Collins 2008

events.title: c.1903 Pancho Villa visited Benson, Bill Williams
events.description: Circle Bar Ranch Bill Williams was friends w Pancho Villa; Ida Williams born c 1900 had her picture taken sitting in PV lap at age 3 while he visited Benson
events.tags: Individuals, Poncho Villa, Bill Williams, Ida Williams

events.title: early 1900s more Tohono O'Odahm left the area moving to San Xavier
events.description: source?

events.title: 1900 ish  first survey for fishes, UA botantist records vegetation composition and changs in Southern Arizona
events.description: Watershed damage from settlement of S. AZ continues with long term implications; Second flood cycle;

events.title: Rangeland severely denuded-ranchers concerned about future of industry
Record of  fish distribution and species descriptions
events.description: Chamberlian 1904

events.title: 1905 A 75-ft tunnel excavated into Colossal Cave in order to mine bat guano.
events.description: Tunnel serves today as bat opening

events.title: Kentucky Camps's Stetson dies in fall from Santa Rita Hotel window in Tucson on May 20th.
events.description: Ky Camp   Az Daily Start  May 21, 1905;  McAneny begins lengthy divorce proceedings. No further gold mining takes place.

events.title: 1905 to 1910 National Forest System in Arizona was initiated by establishment of 'Forest Reserves'
events.description: See Collins 2008 for details

events.title: 1905 Federal lands in T21S,R18E (including what became the Research Ranch) reserved for Huachuca Forest Reserve
events.description: Research Ranch.  See Collins 2008

events.title: 1906 Antiquities Act preserves prehistoric, historic & scientifically significant sites, creates national monuments
events.description: Still in use in 2013

events.title: 1906 Kentucky Camp's Santa Rita WMCo sold at Sheriffi's Sale (F.L. Orell 1998)
events.description: Kentucky Camp

events.title: 1907 The Huachuca Forest Reserve renamed 'Huachuca National Forest' - see Collins 2008
events.description: 1908 The Huachuca National Forest was renamed the Garaces National Forest.- see Collins 2008

events.title: 1908 – Colonel Potter survey proposed area for preservation
events.description: 1908-1910 survey done to identify the boundaries of these private lands which were not available for homesteading by settlers moving into the AZ territory; done by cadastral land surveyos working for the General Land Office (Collins 2008)

events.title: Santa Cruz Fair and Rodeo Association formed
1910 – AZ first hydrologist designed a dam;
1910? San Xavier Reservation
events.description: Established later than Tohono O'odham Reservation lands

events.title: 1910 Kentucky Camp. Louis Hummel acquires the property. Begins using it for cattle ranching
1912 Arizona granted statehood
events.description: 1912 Arizona Statehood Act gave title to all unreserved Sections 2, 16,32 & 35 in each township for 'school sections' to be held in Trust for support of a public school system. Title of Section 16 (NW corner of RR, passed to the State--Collins 2008

events.title: 1912 Federal cadastral land survey of federal public domains lands south of Babocomari Grant.
events.description: Delineated townships and sections for homesteads. See Collins 2008

events.title: 1916 Stock Raising Homestead Act (an amendment to Homestead Act) passed to enable ranchers to acquire land without cultivation. See Collins 2008
events.description: Stock Raising Homestead Act authorizes 640 acre homesteads; separates surface from mineral rights

events.title: 1916 Poncho Villa raids New Mexico
events.description: American enters the World War I

events.title: 1916 Patent to Frances Cuthbert Fenderson approved for portion of what became the Research Ranch.
events.description: Research Ranch.  See Collins 2008

events.title: 1917 Approval of T.B.Titus homestead (currently headquarters of the Research Ranch)
events.description: Research Ranch.  See Collins 2008

events.title: 1917 Colossal Cave name promoted in print.
events.description: Alfred Trippel, businessman, and US Forest Ranger Jim Westfall promote the cave which is deemed in print Colossal Cave.  Prof Byron Cummings leads expedtiions, survey and maps cave, finds 2 human skeletons and Indian artifacts
events.tags: Colossal Cave, Individuals, Alfred Trippel, Jim Westfall, Prof Byron Cummings

events.title: 1920 Mineral Leasing Act:  oil, gas, coal, phosphate sodium etc
1920s turbine pumps
1920s – AZ Game and Fish started releasing bull frog across the state
1921/1922 – oral history shows major snowstorm and drought
1921 Homestead Patent No. 803174 and Stock Raising Homestead Patent No. 803175 to James L. Finley (Section 14 - the Research Ranch)
events.description: Research Ranch - see Collins 2008

events.title: 1921 Corrective Homestead Patent No. 813897 to Francis Cuthbert Fenderson (Section 22-the Research Ranch)
events.description: Research Ranch - see Collins 2008

events.title: 1922 Homestead Patent No. 684794 to Juan Telles (Section 15, portions of 14,23 - the Research Ranch)
events.description: Research Ranch - see Collins 2008

events.title: 1922 Homestead Patent No. 855360 to Thaddeus B. Titus (Incl  land in Section 27-the Research Ranch)
events.description: Research Ranch - see Collins 2008

events.title: 1923 Homestead Patent No. 922230 to John D. Riggs (Section 28 - the Research Ranch)
events.description: Research Ranch - see Collins 2008

events.title: 1924 Stock Raising Homestead Patent No. 931438 to Willard T. Roath (Section 23- the Research Ranch)8
events.description: Research Ranch - see Collins 2008

events.title: 1923-1934 Colossal Cave guided tours
events.description: Schmidt runs guided tours with guests on ropes and unimproved passages.

events.title: 1928  Empire Ranch and Mtn Springs Ranch change owership.
events.description: Vails sell the Empire Ranch to Frank and Henry Boice, who start selling off portions of it.  Pete McDaniel buys Mountain Springs Ranch
events.tags: Land Status, Individuals Vails, Boices, McDaniel

events.title: 1930s Kennedys at J-Six Ranch.
events.description: Joe and Jack Kennedy sent a summer uring their teens; they assisted in building a small adobe bldg.

events.title: ?1930s Was the Cienega Creek one of the last remaining perennial waters near Tucson.
events.description: Maybe one f the last that is primarily groundwater dependent?     ?When did Santa Cruz ast flow perenially (not effuluence dependent?

events.title: 1931 – AZ cotton decision giving all rights to groundwater
events.description: 1931 – AZ cotton decision, based on legal analysis of hydrology (information from 1912 used in decision) – effect was to essentially give all rights to groundwater, not surface water [no protection in AZ for surface water --- groundwater withdrawal causing impacts now]

events.title: 1934 Taylor Grazing Act passed to regulate access for grazing on public lands
events.description: 1934 Taylor Grazing Act authorized grazing districts and grazing regulations

events.title: 193x  Border Patrol begins
Ranchers oppose mesquite encroachment
1933 Colossal Cave Mtn Park - La Posta Quemada Ranch for hotel
events.description: Cattleman Charles Day buys Mtn Springs Ranch from McDaniel; renames it La Posta Quemada Ranch; build a house at hotel site
events.tags: Colossal Cave Mtn Park, Development (Tourism), Individuals Charles Day, McDaniel

events.title: 1934 Colossal Cave lease goes to Arizona
events.description: Frank Schmidt relinguishes his Colossal Cave leases to Arizona; clearin way for federal funds to be used for improvements in Park
events.tags: Colossal Cave, Land Status, Individuals Frank Schmidt

events.title: May 1934 Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) at Colossal Cave
events.description: Company 858 relocates from Randolph Park Camp in Tucson to CC.  Work starts on trails, handrails, and lighting I the Cave and  camp construction.  Camp Sp-10-A located on La Posta Quemada Ranch.  Some bldgs still in use; 1936 CCC work in cave completed; 1937 campground work and th stone barbeque ramada in La Sevilla picnic Area
events.tags: Federal, Colossal Cave Mtn Prk, Organization

events.title: 1933-1934, 1938 drought 'wild horses' collected
1936 first aerial photographs of CW (looking at soil erosion) creek, lst aerial photos NRCS topo survey of cienega
events.description: with NRCS assistance, this survey shows that the arroyo had reached approximate deth of modern day but widening continued

events.title: Certificate of water right to divert cienega creek at dam
1936-1938 Dust Bowl and droughts leading to migration into Arizona
1937 Grazing Region 9 established (Phoenix)
events.description: under Taylor Grazing Act

events.title: c. 1938 Colossal Cave La Posta Quemada Ranch 33,000 acres
events.description: Charles Day combine lands for La Posta Quemada Ranch, Fed and state grazing leases and patented lands totaling 33,000 aces running 600 head of cattle
events.tags: Colossal Cave mtn Park,  Individuals Charles Day

events.title: 1940 Lehmann Lovegrass and Boer Lovegrass planted on Babocomari Ranch by U.S. Soil Conservation Service as range improvement.
events.description: 1940 Lehmann Lovegrass and Boer Lovegrass (exotic grasses from Africa) were planted on Babocomari Ranch by U.S. Soil Conservation Service as range improvement.  See Bock & Bock 2000  LL: Non-natives species can cause trouble for native ecosystems

events.title: 1941 Cienega Creek streamflow measurements - baseline
events.description: Streamflow measurements on Cienega creek (earliest baseflow measurements) ; Leonarad Halpenny makes base flow measurements

events.title: 1943 Research Ranch state land auction
events.description: 1943 State Land Department auctioned 2 parcels of County Bond Trust lands in T21S,R18E (Research Ranch): 320 acres of Section 17 to N.E. Clark; 40 acres Section 23 to Willard T. Roath. See Collins 2008

events.title: 1944 Pima County leases Colossal Cave Park from the State Land Department;
events.description: Frank Schmidt Supervisor continues personally or through managers until age 84  (died June 14, 1957)
events.tags: Arizona, Land Status, Colossal Cave, Individuas Frank Schmidt

events.title: by 1961 Praire dogs and antelope disappear
events.description: B.T. Praire dogs extirpated from AZ 1961; pronghorn extirpated from Valley

events.title: 1946 US Grazing Service ended; became BLM
Hollywood Filming comes to the watershed
events.description: 1946 Duel in the Sun, 1948 Red River; 1959  Last Train from Gun Hill; Gunsmoke, Bonanza; almost 50 movies

events.title: 1950-1960 Deep long-lasting drought
1954 The Bureau of Land Management re-organizes creating the state office system
events.description: The BLM Arizona State Office created to oversee Arizona public lands

events.title: 1956 Colossal Cave Mountain Park is sublet by Pima County to a private partnership
events.description: Joe Maierhauser and Earl Brockelsby were the partners in the agreement; then just Joe M in 1964
events.tags: Colossal Cave Mtn Park, Land status, Individuals Joe Maierhauser, Earl Brockelby

events.title: 1958 Colossal Cave Mtn Park - La Posta Quemada Ranch sold
events.description: 1958 Charles Day sells La Posta Quemada Ranch to Joseph Timan nvestor and developer who sells to Orel Burris, a cattleman and entrepreneur
events.tags: Colossal Cave Mtn Park, Land status, Individuals Charles Day, Orel Burris

events.title: 1960s Proposal to damn Cienega Creek at Benson highway bridge ( industrial complex and lake)
events.description: Proposal never happened, but created a legacy of zoning in the are that was only repealed with the establishment of the Las Cienegas

events.title: 1959 Frank and Ariel Appleton purchased the Clark Ranch (later to become the Research Ranch)
events.description: - see Braun 1970
events.tags: Research Ranch, Land Status, Individuals Frank and Ariel Appleton

events.title: 1960 Public Sale Patent No. 1215504 to Francis Henry Appleton (lots 4 & 5 adjacent to Homestead Patent No. 855360)
events.description: - now within boundary of Research Ranch --see Collins 2008

events.title: 1960 Public Land Administrative Act allows donations & cooperative agreements to improve & better manage public lands
The last Hummels (Floss and Wert Fenter) stop ranching and sell the property to ANAMAX.
events.description: Kentucky Camp, Orell 1998
events.tags: Kentucky Camp, Land Status, Family Hummels

events.title: 1962 Land Exchange Patent 02-62-0119 to Frank Appleton (1076 acres in Sections 27,28 - the Research Ranch) from U.S. Forest Service (3rd party exchange)
events.description: Research Ranch, See Collins 2008
events.tags: Research Ranch, Land Status, US Forest Service

events.title: 1964  Aerial photos showed that Cienega Creek did not have cottonwood gallery forest as it does today
events.description: Need more details on these photos

events.title: 1964 The Wilderness Act passed
events.description: Arizona Wilderness Act did not pass until 1990 ish

events.title: 1964 RCA proposes satellite city near Cienega Creek
events.description: Julia Fonseca has details

events.title: 1964 Joe Maierhauser becomes sole proprietor of sublease of Colossal Cave Park from Pima County
events.tags: Individual Joe Maierhauser, Colossal Cave, Land Status

events.title: early to mid 1960s Fedral Civil Defense Dept. names Colossal Cave a fall-out shelter slated for Pima Co. and City of Tucson goverment officials.
events.description: Boxes of food & barrels of water stored in Cave's Side Routes

events.title: 1965 Land and Water Conservation Fund established for fed acquisiiton of outdoor recreation areas
1965 Phoenix District BLM Office established (included Tucson lands)
1965 Another fire on La Posta Quemada Ranch destoys headquarters house located where Mtn Springs Grove is today
events.description: Colossal Cave Mountain Park

events.title: 1965 Harold C. Tovrea conveyed the Swinging H Ranch (in Sections 14,13,23,27 T21S,R18E) to Ariel Bryce Appleton ---Deed recorded in Santa Cruz County, AZ. Dock 064, Page 98-100
1966 National Historic Preservation Act expands protection of prehistoric & historic properties
1967 - Gila top minnow first listed (most important site in US); current ESA
1967 John S. Sullivan buys La Posta Quemada Ranch, reinstates it as a working cattle ranch, builds the headquarters house today occupied by the Museum
events.description: Colossal Cave Mountain Park
events.tags: Colossal Cave Mtn Park, Individual John Sullivan

events.title: 1968 – Boice sold to GAC--- went out of ranching and into housing;
events.description: 1968 – Boice sold to GAC (GAC sold to Anamax around 72, for water supply for mining in Santa Ritas)--- went out of ranching and into housing;

events.title: 1968  Cattle were removed from the Elgin Hereford Cattle Ranch (later to become the Research Ranch)
events.description: Research Ranch, see Bock& Bock 2000

events.title: 1969 The Research Ranch, Inc. was incorporated as a not-for profit Arizona Corporation to manage the former Elgin Hereford Cattle Ranch (Appleton)
events.description: Articles of Incorporation, Dock 106 Page 73, State of Arizona, Certificate of Incorporation #77060 issued 15 Sept 1969 by Milton Husky, Chairman, ACC;  Appleton Research Ranch created, cattle removed, native grasses improved

events.title: 1969 Gulf American Corp purchases Empire Ranch for proposed real estate development;
events.description: Boice family continues to reside at ranch under lease

events.title: 1969 National Environmental Policy Act requires federal agencies to assess impacts of actions on environment
1969 – Canelo Hills Cienega preserve purchased by TNC; Patagonia-Sonoita creek preserve around same time
(year?)- Anamax drilled test holes
events.description: – this later gave Donaldson the flexibility to do things on landscape

events.title: 1970s Movies at Colossal Cave and TV special 'The Outlaw Cat of Colossal Cave'
1972 Release of Black-tailed Prairie Dogs on the Research Ranch failed.  The Research Ranch Annual Report August 31, 1972
1972 Dr. Jay Schnell hired as Director of the Research Ranch, The Research Ranch Annual Report August 31, 1973
1972 First thesis completed on the Research Ranch  ---Nicholson, R.A., 1972.  Grama (Bouteloua Lag.) Communities in a Southern Arizona Grassland
1972-1973 Steve Boice assumes Empire Ranch management; 1973 Poncho Boice killed in plance accident
1973  Breeding program for endangered Bolson tortoise under way on the Research Ranch;
events.description: Appleton, Ariel, 1973.  The Research Ranch, A Dream Becomes Reality, National Parks & Conservation Magazine, Dec.

events.title: 1973 Vegetation on the Research Ranch shifts from Short-grass to Mid-grass prairie after 3 yrs without domestic livestock.
events.description: Charles Bonham, PhD quoted in Newsweek, Sept. 24, 1973

events.title: 1973 Endangered Species Act requires conservation of threatened & endangered plants, animals, ecosystems
1974 Anamax Miniing Co purchases the Empire Ranch from Gulf American;
events.description: Boice family lease is discontinued and cattle sold

events.title: Big conflict about Empire Ranch satelite city--see Julia for details
1975 Bomber Burn:  Fire in sacaton on Research Ranch started by jettison from aircraft; see Bock & Bock 2000
events.description: 1975  Larry and Marsha Michel are Directors of the Research Ranch ;  The Research Ranch, Inc., Annual Report August 31, 1975
events.tags: Fire, Research Ranch, Individuals Larry and Marsha Michel

events.title: 1975 - John Donaldson begins ranching for Anamax --- lessons about best practice, but fell down on Cienega creek itself – BLM and Donaldson started fencing out the creek and riparian wash area extends out
events.description: Best Pasture grazing rotation helped uplands but damaged riparian areas (one excluded psture had excellent riparian conditions - Cold Spring area)

events.title: 1975 John S. Sullivan sells La Posta Quemada to Jack Lewis, rancher and developer with dreams of condominiums and using Ranch as resort/guest ranch
events.tags: Land Status, Colossal Cave Mountain Park

events.title: 1975 Arthur and Mary Jane Kelly purchsed Old Vail Post Office; became Vail Food Store until 1994
1975 Neal and Diana Hanna moved on Empirita Ranch (Pantana Townsites) working cattle Ranch caretakers to present Natural Preserve
events.description: Source of many creek observations such as: in 1975 new Tucson East Marsh Station and a lot of air smugglers landing in these areas
events.tags: Family Hannahs, Cienega Creek Natural Preserve

events.title: 1975  Public Land Order 5835 withdrew 355 acres of National Forest lands for Research Natural area and withdrew this area from mining claims.   See Collins 2008
events.description: (Section 26,T21S,R18E; Research Ranch)
events.tags: Land Status, Research Ranch, US Forest Service

events.title: 1976 Federal Land Policy and Management Act requires public lands be managed for multiple uses and sustained yield through land use planning
1977 Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act ensures environmental safeguards of mining & reclamation
Rosemont EIS for Asarco is prepared by UA
1978 Public Rangelands Improvement Act requires inventory, trend analysis, improvements of public rangelands
1979 Archaeological Resources Protection Act requires permits, provides criminal, civil penalties for violations
1979-81 – pronghorn re-introduced by game and fish into CW
events.description: (had been gone since 50/60s) – mix in species (Donaldsons allowed them to be introduced)

events.title: 1980 Memorandum of Agreement transferred management of The Research Ranch from The Research Ranch Foundation (aka The Research Ranch, Inc.) to National Audubon Society.
events.description: Name changed to the Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch of the National Audubon Society, Inc.  See Bock & Bock 2000

events.title: 1980 – Groundwater management act --- designated AMA boundaries;
events.description: decision to exclude area of Rosemont mine (owned by Asarco), excluded portions of Davidson Canyon

events.title: 1980-1991 Drs. Carl and Jane Bock serve as Research Directors of the Research Ranch under contract to National Audubon Society.  Research Ranch Archives
events.description: 1981-1982 Vern Hawthorne hired as Resident Director of the Research Ranch --Research Ranch Archives
events.tags: Research Ranch, Family Bocks, Individual Vern Hawthorne

events.title: 1982 Jack Lewis sells most of his interest in La Posta Quemada Ranch to Armond Anson, head of a Cleveland consortium of investors, still looking at a resort.
1982 Memorandum of Understanding signed between the Forest Service and National Audubon Society
events.description: 'to cooperate in studies to encourage research on factors related to maintaining and improving management of Southwestern desert grasslands and to maintain the established Elgin Research Natural Area.'  MOU dated June 14, July 28 & Juy 13, 1982; 1982-1988  Dr. Mark Stromberg hired as Resident Director of the Research Ranch ---Research Ranch Archives

events.title: Illegal grading of Ranch del Lago
1983 – Walter Armor (rancher, Flying R/Bar V) – submitted first instream flow for Cienega creek; downstream was horizon corporation (illegally graded right before 83 flood)
1983 – flood—created areas that flowed for several years after, based on this a development plan for 12,000 units did not need surface water rights…effects)
events.description: Flood recharges Cieienga and causes cottonwood recruitment; Hannas living on the Reserve couldn’t cross the creek for 6 weeks

events.title: 1984 Montogmery associates begins monitoring streamflow

Mexican-American War
events.description: The Mexican?American War, also known as the Mexican War, the U.S.?Mexican War, the Invasion of Mexico, the U.S. Intervention, or the United States War Against Mexico, was an armed conflict between the United States of America and the United Mexican States from 1846 to 1848 in the wake of the 1845 U.S. annexation of Texas, which Mexico considered part of its territory despite the 1836 Texas Revolution.

events.title: Gadsden Purchase
events.description: Gadsden Purchase from Mexico acquires Empire Ranch lands as part of US. Anglo-American settlers begin to occupy Sonoita Valley

events.title: Civil War
Yellowstone National Park
Hatch Act
Forest Reserve establishes
events.description: In 1891, Congress established the Forest Reserve, which officially came into existence under the Department of Agriculture six years later.

events.title: Organic Administration Act
Coronado National Forest Reserve establishes
events.description: The Coronado National Forest Reserve was established in 1908 resulting from combination of several local Forest Reserves in Southeast Arizona and Southwest New Mexico.

events.title: "Transfer Reductions"  Policy
events.description: The management of the Coronado National Forest Reserve began with an emphasis on reducing the stocking rate and a policy of "transfer reductions" requiring a 10% reduction in permitted numbers each time a permit was reissued. The policy was effective and resulted in removal of hundreds of cattle from Coronado. By the early 1950s, many ranges were no longer overstocked and the policy was rescinded (Allen 1989).

events.title: WWI
National Park Service Organic Act
The Roosevelt conservation movement.
events.description: http://memory.loc.gov/ammem/amrvhtml/cnchron4.html

events.title: Farm Bill
events.description: In the United States, the farm bill is the primary agricultural and food policy tool of the federal government. The comprehensive omnibus bill is passed every 5 years or so by the United States Congress and deals with both agriculture and all other affairs under the purview of the United States Department of Agriculture. The farm bill was first created during the Great Depression to give financial assistance to farmers who were struggling due to an excess crop supply creating low prices, and also to control and ensure an adequate food supply.[4] The first farm bill, known as the Agriculture Adjustment Act (AAA), was passed by Congress in 1933 as a part of Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal.[5] The bill allowed farmers to receive payment for not growing food on a percentage of their land as allocated by the United States Secretary of Agriculture. It also enabled the government to buy excess grain from farmers, which could then be sold later if bad weather or other circumstances negatively affected output. The AAA also included a nutrition program, the precursor to food stamps.[6]

events.title: Taylor Grazing Act.
events.description: The Taylor Grazing Act was signed in 1934 to stop injury to the public grazing lands by preventing overgrazing and soil deterioration.

events.title: Soil Conservation Service establishes.
events.description: The agency was founded largely through the efforts of Hugh Hammond Bennett, a soil conservation pioneer who had worked for the Department of Agriculture from 1903 to 1952. Bennett's motivation was based on his knowledge of the detrimental effects of soil erosion and the impacts on U.S lands that led to the Dust Bowl in the 1930s. On September 13, 1933, the Soil Erosion Service was formed in the Department of the Interior, with Bennett as chief. The service was transferred to the Department of Agriculture on March 23, 1935, and was shortly thereafter combined with other USDA units to form the Soil Conservation Service by the Soil Conservation and Domestic Allotment Act of 1935. Hugh Bennett continued as chief, a position he held until his retirement in 1952. On October 20, 1994, the agency was renamed to the Natural Resources Conservation Service as part of the Federal Crop Insurance Reform and Department of Agriculture Reorganization Act of 1994.

events.title: The Bankhead-Jones Farm Tenant Act
WWII
Conservation Needs Inventory
events.description: By the early 1940s, The Soil Conservation Service (SCS) realized natural resources information was required to develop programs and set priorities for various conservation needs throughout the country. After assembling and analyzing the available resources data, SCS published in 1945 a report on U.S. soil and water conservation needs, which became the Conservation Needs Inventory (CNI) and prepared the ground for future inventories.

events.title: Wild Horse Protection Act
The Multiple Use Sustained Yield Act
The Wilderness Act
Land and Water Conservation Act
The National Historic Preservation Act
National Wild and Scenic Rivers System/Wild and Scenic Rivers Act
National Environmental Policy Act
events.description: National Environmental Policy Act - Federal angecies begin evaluating environmental effects of all decisions, including grazing permit renewals

events.title: Wild Horses and Burros Act
Clean Water Act
Endangered Species Act
events.description: The Endangered Species Act of 1973 is designed to protect critically imperiled species from extinction as a "consequence of economic growth and development untempered by adequate concern and conservation."

events.title: Forest and Range Renewable Resources Planning Act
Federal Noxious Weed Act
Safe Drinking Water Act
events.description: The Safe Drinking Water Act (SDWA) was established to protect the quality of drinking water in the U.S. This law focuses on all waters actually or potentially designed for drinking use, whether from above ground or underground sources.

events.title: Federal Land Policy and Management Act
Resource Conservation and Recovery Act
events.description: The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) gives EPA the authority to control hazardous waste from the "cradle-to-grave." This includes the generation, transportation, treatment, storage, and disposal of hazardous waste. RCRA also set forth a framework for the management of non-hazardous solid wastes. The 1986 amendments to RCRA enabled EPA to address environmental problems that could result from underground tanks storing petroleum and other hazardous substances.

events.title: Public Rangelands Improvement Act
Food Security Act
events.description: Food Security Act requires all farmers to have a conservation plan on HEL soils and wetlands to participate in USDA programs, inclduing commodities.

events.title: Alien Species Prevention and Enforcement Act
The Rescission Act
Federal Agriculture Improvement and Reform Act
Environmental Quality Incentives Program
events.description: The Environmental Quality Incentives Program (EQIP) provides a steady and major source of annual support since 1997. In 1997, NRCS was authorized to provide $2 million throughout Arizona through EQIP and it was gradually increased to $10 million in 2002 and reached $20 million in 2006. A total of 177.5 million dollars was invested from 1997 through 2012. Most of the EQIP money was spent for water development, drought fund, and planning, implement of conservation practices. It?s a great help to maintain and improve rangeland conditions, especially to alleviate the drought damage brought by the continues warming and drying climate starting the late 1990s.

events.title: Agricaltural Research, Extension, and Education Reform Act
The Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan
events.description: The Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan (SDCP) is guiding regional efforts to conserve the best lands and most precious resources for future generations of Pima County residents to enjoy. The Plan combines short-term actions with long-range land-use decisions in Pima County, one of the most biologically diverse counties in the U.S. From cactus-studded deserts to conifer forests, the diverse landscape of Pima County is the home to a million residents from diverse ethnic and cultural backgrounds, and contains a rich diversity of plant and animal life.

events.title: Agriculture Risk Protection Act
Food, Conservation, and Energy Act
Arizona becomes a state.
The Arizona surface water code was enacted
events.description: Early in its history, Arizona adopted the doctrine of prior appropriation to govern the use of surface water. This doctrine is based on the tenet of ?first in time, first in right? which means that the person who first puts the water to a beneficial use acquires a right that is better than later appropriators of the water.Prior to June 12, 1919, a person could acquire a surface water right simply by applying the water to a beneficial use and posting a notice of the appropriation at the point of diversion. On June 12, 1919, the Arizona surface water code was enacted.  Now known as the Public Water Code, this law provides that a person must apply for and obtain a permit in order to appropriate surface water unless: 1. The water is from the mainstream of the lower Colorado river, in which case a contract with the Secretary of the Interior is required. 2.The person or the person?s predecessor-in-interest, lawfully appropriated the water prior to June 12, 1919 and the person or the person?s predecessor-in-interest has filed a statement of claim for the appropriation with the state. 3.The water is stored in a stockpond constructed after June 12, 1919 and before August 27, 1977.

events.title: National Environmental Policy Act
The First Earthday
Environmental Protection Agency estibishes.
events.description: The United States Environmental Protection Agency[2] (EPA or sometimes USEPA) is an agency of the U.S. federal government which was created for the purpose of protecting human health and the environment by writing and enforcing regulations based on laws passed by Congress.[3] The EPA was proposed by President Richard Nixon and began operation on December 2, 1970, after Nixon signed an executive order.

events.title: National Forest Management Act
Colossal Cave Mountain Park Expansion
events.description: Pima County?s first efforts to conserve Colossal Cave began in 1944, when the County leased almost 500 acres from the State Land Department for purposes of a park.  Using 1986 voter-approved bond funds for park land acquisition, the County began to establish the mountain park to protect the cave in 1989 and a Pima County park was formally established in 1992.  Acquisitions included the historic Posta Quemada Ranch, which is also the site of a 120-year old stagecoach station.  Colossal Cave Mountain Park (CCMP) supports habitat for almost half of the bat species in the State of Arizona, including the endangered Lesserlong-nosed bat.  CCMP also protects large segments of lush riparian vegetation along Agua Verde Creek, a major tributary to Cienega Creek.

events.title: Walden and Other Properties that Contribute to the Reserve
events.description: The properties were acquired because of their basic ecological and habitat values. Walden Property McKenzie Property Poteet Property Amadon and Nunez Properties

events.title: Cienega Creek Natural Preserve Expansion
events.description: Recognizing the incredible importance of Cienega Creek and its watershed, the Board of Supervisors established the Cienega Creek Natural Preserve in 1986 using voter-approved bond funds for floodprone land.  Spanning 4,000 acres, the Preserve protects 12 miles of the lower reaches of Cienega Creek, which supports native endangered fish species, provides aquifer recharge, and provides important natural flood control protections that lessen impacts to the developed areas in the Tucson Basin.  The Preserve also hosts the historic railroad town of Pantano, along with many archaeological features, including bedrock mortars.

events.title: The acquisition of Bar V Ranch
events.description: Pima County?s acquisition of the Bar V Ranch contributes to the conservation of one of the most important wildlife movement corridors in the Cienega Valley.  The 14,400 acre Bar V Ranch is located between the Rincon and Santa Rita Mountains, andadjacent to the County?s Cienega Creek Natural Preserve.  The ranch includes a significant portion of Davison Canyon, an important tributary and water source to Cienega Creek and the Tucson Basin.  Acquisition of the Bar V Ranch preserves a large intact piece of the Empire-Cienega landscape and protects important riparian habitat crucial for several vulnerable species.

events.title: The acquisition of Sands Ranch
events.description: In its entirety, the historic Sands Ranch totals 64,000 acres, spanning east of the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area to the San Pedro River in Cochise County.  With the assistance of the Arizona Land and Water Trust, the County acquired the 5,000 acres of the Sands Ranch located in the far southeast corner of Pima County.  This acquisition further connects a system of publicly-owned lands from the Santa Rita Mountains to the Whetstone Mountains, especially when coupled with the County?s subsequent acquisition of the adjacent Clyne Ranch.  Not only does it contribute to the health of the Cienega Watershed, but also conserves high quality native grasslands and wildlife movement corridors.

events.title: The acquisition of Empirita Ranch
events.description: The Empirita (little Empire) Ranch actually broke off from the larger Empire Ranch in 1941. In 1991 and 92, the Pima County Flood Control District purchased 360 acres of the Empirita Ranch. In 2001, Pima County?s acquisition of the 2,700-acre Empirita property conserved the last remaining portions of the private land that comprised the historic Empirita Ranch.  With assistance from the Arizona Land and Water Trust, the County negotiated the purchase of the Empirita property, along with the owner assigning the County its contractual right to withdraw up to 1,600 acre feet of groundwater annually from the Cienega Creek Basin.  The Empirita acquisition expands upon already conserved reserves, including the Coronado National Forest, the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area, and the County?s Bar V Ranch, Empirita Ranch and Cienega Creek Natural Preserve.

events.title: The acquisition of Clyne Ranch
events.description: The County?s acquisition of 5,000 acres of the Sands Ranch,located east of the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area, in December 2008, created an interconnected corridor of conserved lands spanning from the Santa Rita Mountains to the Whetstone Mountains.  With the assistance of the Arizona Land and Water Trust, the County then acquired the Clyne Ranch parcels, located adjacent to the County?s Sands Ranch and also east of the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area, totaling 880 acres.  In addition, development restrictions were placed on 90 acres maintained by the seller. The ranch is an integral part of this assemblage of publicly-owned lands and further contributes to this corridor through the Cienega Valley.  The Clyne Ranch parcels, like the Sands Ranch, contains high quality native grasslands found in the Sonoita Valley area.

events.title: The Civilian Conservation Corps efforts in Southern Arizona.
events.description: The Southwest's first Civilian Conservation Corps constructed hundreds of miles of drift fences and numerous water developments on the Coronado during the 1920s and 1930s.Allotments with relatively light stocking rates showed marked improvement. However, the goal of these water developments and fencing were on increasing range capacity and separating animals.  Yet little attention was given to the basic principles of range management such as improving livestock distribution through fencing or rotational grazing (Allen, 1989).  This resulted in heavy use in new areas and brought significant forage competition with resident wildlife.
